item.title: South Africa Central Bank Deputy Governor Says Inflation Goal Is Too Wide
item.description: South African Reserve Bank Deputy Governor Fundi Tshazibana said there is broad agreement that the country’s 3% to 6% inflation target range is too wide.
item.dc:creator: Ntando Thukwana

media:content.media:description: Fundi Tshazibana

item.title: Milei Stumbles in Bid to Unchain Farmers as Soy Tax Break Ends
item.description: President Javier Milei’s vow to unleash Argentina’s beleaguered farmers is faltering after a decision to raise taxes on soy exports by about seven percentage points.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Gilbert

media:content.media:description: A combine harvester cuts through a field of soybean plants in San Jose de la Esquina, Argentina.

item.title: Meloni Looks to Moody’s to End Italy’s Near-Junk Status
item.description: Italy is just two days away from the chance to start shaking off the near-junk status that has hung over Giorgia Meloni’s premiership.
item.dc:creator: Alessandra Migliaccio

media:content.media:description: Giorgia Meloni Photographer: Alessia Pierdomenico/Bloomberg

item.title: Iceland Cuts Rate and Signals More Moves Hinge on Inflation
item.description: Iceland’s central bank lowered its key interest rate for a fifth straight meeting, and signaled further reductions depend on inflation moving closer to its target.
item.dc:creator: Ott Ummelas

media:content.media:description: The logo of Sedlabanki Islands, Iceland's central bank in Reykjavik.

item.title: Johnson Says Deal Reached on Raising SALT Cap to $40,000
item.description: House Speaker Mike Johnson said Republicans have reached an agreement to increase the state and local tax deduction to $40,000, suggesting a resolution to one of the final issues holding up President Donald Trump’s economic bill.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Nacha Cattan

media:content.media:description: House Speaker Mike Johnson

item.title: Half of Turkish Firms in Red as Tight Monetary Policy Bites
item.description: Turkish companies that once backed the central bank’s return to orthodox monetary policy are now reporting widespread losses, as borrowing costs near 50% and fears of a hard landing grow.
item.dc:creator: Tugce Ozsoy

media:content.media:description: Skyscrapers in the International Finance Center, including the Turkish central bank, center, in Istanbul.

item.title: Winners and Losers in South Africa’s Latest Budget Attempt
item.description: South African Finance Minister Enoch Godongwana presented a third version of the national budget to lawmakers in Cape Town on Wednesday after months of wrangling over tax increases.
item.dc:creator: Michael Cohen

media:content.media:description: Street vendors at an outdoor market in Pretoria, South Africa. Photographer: Waldo Swiegers/Bloomberg

item.title: Highlights of South African Finance Minister’s Reworked Budget
item.description: Below are the highlights of South Africa’s third iteration of the 2025 budget announced by Finance Minister Enoch Godongwana in Cape Town on Wednesday, after two previous versions were withdrawn because of disagreements within the governing coalition over taxes.
item.dc:creator: Monique Vanek

media:content.media:description: Over the next three years, 1.03 trillion rand will be allocated to public infrastructure. Photographer: Waldo Swiegers/Bloomberg

item.title: Milei’s Cuts Have Argentines Driving New Cars With Paper License Plates
item.description: Mariela Mailhe sells imported cars in one of Argentina’s flashiest neighborhoods. They come with electronically adjustable leather seats and panoramic sunroofs, but thanks in part to Javier Milei’s austerity campaign they roll off the lot with paper license plates.
item.dc:creator: Ignacio Olivera Doll

media:content.media:description: Traffic on the General Paz avenue in Buenos Aires. Photographer: Luis Robayo/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Mnuchin Flags US Budget Deficit as Bigger Worry Than Trade Gap
item.description: Former United States Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin said he’s more alarmed by the country’s growing budget deficit than its trade imbalances, and urged Washington to prioritize fiscal repair.
item.dc:creator: Anto Antony

media:content.media:description: Steven Mnuchin Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB’s Guindos Sees Price Target Hit Sooner Rather Than Later
item.description: The European Central Bank isn’t far from achieving its 2% inflation target, helped by a stronger euro and falling energy costs, according to Vice President Luis de Guindos.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber, Mark Schroers

item.title: Trump Jr. Says ‘Maybe One Day’ He’ll Look to Succeed His Father
item.description: Donald Trump Jr. hinted that he may run for political office and try to succeed his father as US president.
item.dc:creator: Paul Wallace, Beril Akman, Zainab Fattah, Joumanna Bercetche

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump Jr. Photographer: Christopher Pike/Bloomberg

item.title: Chinese Exporters Rush to Meet US Import Demand
item.description: The US-China trade truce last week sparked an immediate revival along one of the world’s most important trade routes, and Guangdong-based supply chain manager Chen Lei was at the forefront.
item.dc:creator: Katia Dmitrieva

item.title: Even After Moody’s, ‘US Is the US’ for Sovereign Wealth Funds
item.description: I’m Chris Anstey, an economics editor in Boston. Today we’re looking at discussion about the US as an investment destination on Day One of the Qatar Economic Forum. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Chris Anstey

item.title: Indonesia Pledges Vigilance on Rupiah After Resuming Rate Cuts
item.description: Indonesia’s central bank stands ready to stabilize the rupiah from the trade war uncertainty, after it cut its benchmark interest rate to address slowing economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Grace Sihombing, Claire Jiao

media:content.media:description: The Bank Indonesia headquarters in Jakarta. Photographer: Rosa Panggabean/Bloomberg

item.title: Merz Advisers See Germany in Stagnation But Recovery in Sight
item.description: Germany’s economy will stagnate this year, though a recovery is in sight thanks to plans to ramp up government spending, Chancellor Friedrich Merz’s independent panel of experts said.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers

item.title: ECB Warns of Ripple Effects From Investors Questioning US Assets
item.description: The European Central Bank warned that heightened investor concern over the riskiness of US assets following Donald Trump’s tariff drive could further jolt the world’s financial system.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Weber, Mark Schroers

media:content.media:description: The European Central Bank headquarters in Frankfurt, Germany, on Friday, May 9, 2025. In March, the ECB projected 0.9% growth this year, followed by 1.2% and 1.3% in 2026 and 2027.

item.title: ECB Will Soon Reach Terminal Rate If Baseline Holds, Kazaks Says
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Martins Kazaks said interest-rate cuts are nearing an end, assuming the base case for inflation stabilizing at 2% over the coming months comes to pass.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Eglitis

media:content.media:description: Martins Kazaks

item.title: UK Bond Yields Climb With Pound as Inflation Dents Rate-Cut Bets
item.description: UK bonds fell and the pound gained after data showed UK inflation rose more than expected in April, leading traders to pare bets on further interest-rate cuts from the Bank of England.
item.dc:creator: Naomi Tajitsu, Vassilis Karamanis, James Hirai

item.title: UK Inflation Surge Prompts Traders to Pare Bets on BOE Cuts
item.description: UK inflation jumped more than forecast to its highest rate in over a year as households were hit by a raft of price increases, prompting investors to pare bets on rate cuts from the Bank of England.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel, Tom Rees

item.title: US-China Tensions Over Chips Risk Hurting Trade Truce, Dialogue
item.description: US-China tech tensions are flaring again, with Beijing threatening legal action against anyone enforcing Washington’s restrictions on Huawei Technologies Co.’s chips, casting a shadow over a recent trade truce and efforts to sustain dialogue.
item.dc:creator: Colum Murphy

media:content.media:description: A Huawei Technologies Co. chip

item.title: Nordea Questions Norway’s Data on Faltering Home Construction
item.description: Norway’s official data showing sluggish housing construction may skew the real picture, according to analysts with Nordea Bank Abp, who cited competing evidence of a rise in housing starts.
item.dc:creator: Ott Ummelas

media:content.media:description: Housing in Stavanger, Norway. Photographer: Naina Helén Jåma/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump Jr. Says Trade Tariffs Will Be Worth It
Japan’s Farm Minister Quits Over Rice Gaffe in Blow to Ishiba
item.description: Japan’s farm minister quit Wednesday after saying he’s never needed to buy rice, a comment that fueled criticism of Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba’s minority government and its handling of rising food prices ahead of an election.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama, Yuko Takeo

media:content.media:description: Taku Eto, center, at the parliament in Tokyo on May 19.

item.title: South Africa Arbiter Proposes More Pay to Avoid Logistics Strike
item.description: A third-party arbiter proposed a higher wage offer to South Africa’s state-owned ports and rail company and its unions in a bid to stave off a potential strike by thousands of logistics workers.
item.dc:creator: Ana Monteiro

media:content.media:description: A worker walks through the terminal as a rail mounted gantry crane, manufactured by Terex Corp., lifts a shipping container on the dockside at the Port of Durban, operated by Transnet SOC Holdings Ltd.'s Ports Authority, in Durban, South Africa, on Friday, May 25, 2018. Transnet last year reduced its seven-year capital-investment plan by 17 percent to 229.2 billion rand in response to lower-than-anticipated freight demand. Photographer: Waldo Swiegers/Bloomberg

item.title: Chinese Authorities Question Metals Bosses in Smuggling Probe
item.description: Chinese authorities have questioned the heads of some of the country’s leading metals merchants and producers as part of an intensifying effort to crack down on critical-minerals smuggling, according to people familiar with the situation.
item.dc:creator: Julian Luk, Alfred Cang

item.title: Bank Indonesia Poised to Resume Rate Cuts as Growth Falters
item.description: Indonesia’s central bank is expected to resume lowering interest rates as the US-China trade truce and the rupiah’s ensuing rebound open up a window of opportunity for policymakers to spur economic growth.
item.dc:creator: Grace Sihombing

media:content.media:description: The Bank Indonesia headquarters beyond the traffic in Jakarta, Indonesia, on Wednesday, Sept. 18, 2024. Indonesia’s central bank is approaching the point where it can start easing borrowing costs as the rupiah keeps strengthening and inflation stays modest. Most economists aren’t convinced that it will happen this week though, before the expected US rate cut.

item.title: G-7 Countries Discuss Tariffs on Low-Value Chinese Products
item.description: Canadian Finance Minister Francois-Philippe Champagne said Group of Seven countries have started discussing tariffs on oversupplied, low-value Chinese products.
item.dc:creator: Erik Hertzberg, Brian Platt, Daniel Flatley

media:content.media:description: Francois-Philippe Champagne Photographer: Cole Burston/Bloomberg

item.title: US Sets the Stage for Duties on Battery Materials From China
item.description: The US Commerce Department set the stage for anti-subsidy duties on imports of key battery components from China, after concluding materials had been unfairly subsidized.
item.dc:creator: Tope Alake

item.title: G-7 Finance Ministers Aim to Avoid Public Spats With US Despite Trade Turmoil
item.description: Finance ministers who’ve gathered in Canada for a Group of Seven meeting this week face a difficult task — trying to find common ground on trade issues while avoiding public conflict with US Treasury Secretary Scott Bessent.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Flatley, Erik Hertzberg, Laura Dhillon Kane

media:content.media:description: Tourists take photos with the Banff town sign, ahead of the G7 Finance Ministers and Central Bank Governors' Meeting in Banff, Alberta, Canada on May 20, 2025. Top finance leaders from the G7 nations gather in Canada starting Tuesday, with concerns including war in Ukraine at the fore while the advanced economies grapple with fallout from US President Donald Trump's sweeping tariffs. (Photo by Cole Burston / AFP) (Photo by COLE BURSTON/AFP via Getty Images)
